oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church: view of rear with addition
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1524 Avenue D, Ensley, Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Color photograph of the back (north) elevation of the church, showing The red brick exterior walls with four rectangular windows of painted glass. A chimney flue extends slightly from the building at the center of the wall. HVAC units and other utility infrastructure is visible at ground level, against the exterior basement wall. A later addition to the 1942 building is to the left, consisting of a small wood-sided enclosure and the sloping roof of a building addition to the left.

Bethel AME Church, whose congregation dates to 1898, was one of the leading churches involved in the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights during the Civil Rights era in Birmingham, particularly in the early years of the organization between 1956 and 1958. The ministers during the Civil Rights era were Rev. Floyd E. Legg and Rev. Edward Mixon. William E. Shortridge, a trustee of the church and local insurance agent and undertaker, was the treasurer of the ACMHR from 1956 to 1964. He assumed the administration of ACMHR when Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth left Birmingham and was the target of death threats and an attempted assassination.
The church location dates to 1907, when the first church was built on the site. That church burned in 1934 and the congregation was able to rebuild in 1942, with significant modifications done in 1952 and 1996.
